Award.AwardTitle: CDI-Type I: Collaborative Research: Gaining Knowledge from Other Patients: Structuring and Searching the Content of Health-Related Web Posts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Individuals with chronic diseases rely more and more on online forums, blogs, and mailing lists to exchange information, practical tips, and stories about their conditions and to get emotional support from their peers. While this type of social networking has become central to the daily lives and decision-making processes of many patients, there has been little research on the quality of the content it conveys, as well as its use and impact in the fields of medicine and public health. On the patients' side, forums are surprisingly technologically poor: users have often no choice but to browse through massive numbers of posts while looking for a particular piece of information. The lack of appropriate tools to organize, analyze and ultimately understand the overwhelming number of health-related, patient-written posts hinders researchers from investigating this medium and hinders patients from using this medium to its full potential.

This project aims at helping both patients and health professionals access online patient-authored information by creating tools to search for information in patient forums. The proposed work spans several fields: natural language processing, data management, information retrieval, public health and behavioral medicine, and it will build the foundations for understanding peer patient posts available through online forums and mailing lists.

This proposal aims at bringing together information processing and medical understanding of patient-centric resources. The work in this project will process texts from an emerging medium, which directly addresses the immediate concerns of patients. The tools designed as part of this project will benefit the researchers who study the behaviors and information needs of patients online. These tools, such as the intelligent search engine for posts, will also enhance the experience of the patients themselves, who are avid users of this medium. In addition to the research agenda, this proposal presents an education plan consistent with the overall goal of bridging the gap between researchers in computer science and researchers in medical fields. In particular, a course is presented that introduces methods of intelligent information processing in the context of research questions important to the fields of public health and medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A large number of patients rely on online health communities to exchange information and emotional support with their peers. This is still a new phenomenon, and several research questions arise to fully understand the ultimate impact of participation in these communities on the patients’ informational and emotional needs. In this project, we investigated the use of computational methods (natural language processing and data mining) to delve into some of these research questions. We focused on online health communities for individuals with breast cancer.

We conducted a survey with patients to gather initial understanding of why patients connect on breast cancer discussion boards and mailing lists, what type of support they get from their peers, and what they wish could be different in these platforms. We confirmed that patients are eager to connect with their peers to obtain and provide knowledge of their disease, share experiences related to cancer, and support each other emotionally through the course of their disease and treatments.

We established a schema of types of discussion topics that typically occur on an online breast cancer community, based on semi-automated content analysis of the entire content of a large, active, and public community. We built computational models, which infer the topics of discussion in a community post. When applying the model to the overall community, which contains more than 3 million posts, we identified the following 10 topics of discussion: treatments (with up to 24% of the posts discussing this topic), symptoms and side effects of treatments (20% of the posts), personal matters (19% of the posts), health systems, such as doctors and insurance companies (19% of the posts), cancer-related diagnoses and other conditions (16% of the posts), resources about cancer, such as scientific articles and websites (15% of the posts), alternative treatments (11% of the posts), daily matters, such as exercise (10% of the posts), nutrition (9% of the posts), and tests, such as genetic testing and imaging (6% of the posts). In the case of breast cancer, considering the overwhelming complexity of treatment choices and understanding of the disease, it is not surprising that such an overwhelming number of posts discuss treatments.

We also built computational models that assess the sentiment of a post in the community, as negative or positive. We applied the sentiment analysis to all the posts in the community, and analyzed the changes in sentiment of the different community members through time. We found that when posting in the community for the first time, members on average had negative posts, but the subsequent posts’ sentiment increased steadily over the next three months of participation in the community. We also found that replies from the community were consistently more positive than original posts in a thread (in other words, the community shows strong emotional support, no matter how new the members are in the community). Finally, we found that different factors played a role in the trends of sentiment through time; for instance stage-IV members form a particular sub-community with patterns of sentiment and usage distinct from others members, and older members are consistently more positive in their posts than younger members.

The computational tools we built, while validated for breast cancer communities, are robust and can be used for different types of online health communities.
